Zene A. tem 26 anos de idade é natural de Gorongosa provincia de Sofala no Centro de Moçambique. Pai de 2 filhos. Para alem dos filhos sustenta a sua mae e seu irmao enviando dinheiro mensalmente. Zene A. é estudante frequentando 11ªClasse do curso nocturno. Veio a Maputo em 2003 para comprir os serviço militar sozinho na familia. É funcionario do ministerio da defesa. Ainda não tem casa própria. Este é o primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku e segundo na vida, onde o primeiro foi no Banco Internacional de Moçambique no valor de 18000,00mt. Conheceu a Hluvuku atraves de colegas que já eram cliente. O maior sonho do senhor Zené é ter sua própria casa.

loans.use: To buy materials to build a house

loans.name: Rakiétou

texts.fr:
Mrs. Rakiétou T. was born December 31, 1987 in Bafilo in the Kara region of Togo. She comes from a modest family and has worked in small business since her childhood. She is married to Mr. Yérima Fousseni and has one child. Since 2006, she has become involved in the sale of grain and charcoal in Adidogomé and Agoè markets. This first loan that she is requesting will allow her to buy three bags of corn, four bags of rice and four bags of sorghum in order to increase her stock of grain over charcoal.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame TRAORE -YAYA Rakiétou est née le 31 décembre 1987 à Bafilo dans la région de la Kara au Togo. Elle est issue d’une famille modeste et exerce le petit commerce depuis son enfance. Elle s’est mariée à monsieur FOUSSENI Yérima et à un enfant. Depuis 2006 elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de céréales et de charbon de bois dans les marchés d’Adidogomé et d’Agoè. Ce premier crédit qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’acheter trois (3) sacs de maïs, quatre (4) sacs de Riz et quatre (4) sacs de sorgho afin de reconstituer son stock de céréales au détriment de charbon de bois.

loans.use: Purchasing grain

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
Sou S. Oa, 49, has a business selling brooms around Phnom Penh city and earns approximately US$8 each day. His wife, Sok Saren, stays at home making the brooms for her husband to sell (pictured). The broom are made from a long grass which grows in the forest. People that live in the outskirts, especially along the railway, have businesses making brooms and selling them throughout Phnom Penh city. The couple began making and selling brooms in 1998. They have three children, all of whom are employed as garment factory workers.

She told a loan officer that every month she needs to spend around US$80 on food and US$15 on utility. Mr. Sou is requesting a loan from Kiva via CREDIT, Kiva's local partner, to purchase the long grass in bulk. This will save money and allow his wife to increase the number of brooms that she can make. The couple plan to distribute the brooms to other small sellers. In the future, if possible, Mr. Sou wants to have a small truck to transport the brooms.

loans.use: To purchase the long grass in bulk that is required to make brooms.

loans.name: Jean Damascene

texts.en:
Greetings from Jean in Gisenyi, Rwanda! Jean is 49 years old, married with 8 children.

Jean sells tomatoes, onions, carrots, and green vegetables in the market. He employs 4 people to help him run the business. He is looking for a loan worth 409,875 Frws to buy fertilizer and chemicals for his crops. The loan repayment period is 8 months, to be repaid monthly.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and chemicals for his crops

loans.name: Romina Rocío

texts.es: La Señora Romina, tiene el negocio en el Mercado de comidas. La señora vive en la zona de Bajo Tacagua una zona muy pobre de la ciudad de La Paz, Bolivia,  vive en la casa familiar de sus padres, ya que no le alcanza el capital para poder tener una casa propia. El prestamo solicitado en EMPRENDER mediante Kiva, servirá para incrementar su capital de trabajo. En lo que respecta a su vida privada, ayuda con los gastos del hogar para ello cuenta con el apoyo de su papá quien tambien aporta a cubrir los gastos familiares y a su vez para mejorar cada vez más su negocio. Es una persona muy responsable, y tiene buenas referencias por parte de sus padres  y por quienes la conocen por la zona.
texts.en:
Romina has a business in the food market. She lives in the Bajo Tacagua neighborhood, a very poor area of La Paz, Bolivia. She lives with her parents because she has not had the money to have her own house. The loan she is requesting from Kiva’s field partner, EMPRENDER, will serve to increase her wages. In her personal life, it will help her and her father cover the household bills and grow her business. She is a very responsible person and has good references from her parents and others that know her from the neighborhood.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raise capital

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca A. is 32 years old and married with two children, one of whom is in school. To support her household, she has been operating a hair salon in her neighborhood for eight years. As the result of her good interpersonal skills and her innovative way of going about her duties, she has attracted many loyal customers to her shop. She notes that, if she is away, her customers find it difficult to adjust to her apprentice, whom she has trained. Rebecca wants the loan to purchase items like hair cream, combs, a hair dryer, and cosmetics so that she can increase her inventory and make a better income for the family’s needs. Rebecca is a member of the group called ‘Nnowm’ (Song). Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. Her picture was taken after a group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more additional hair cream, combs, hair dryer, and cosmetics to increase services.

loans.name: Malasia

texts.es:
Doña Malasia inicio el  negocio a raíz que se quedo sin empleo su esposo, con la liquidación el le puso una mini pulpería viendo que le iba bien visito las oficinas de Adim y solicito su primer crédito, el cual lo invirtió en la compra de productos de primera necesitad, después del crédito, adim la invito a participar en los talleres de capacitación, a los que acudio y participo aplicando en su negocio lo aprendido.
Va al mercado 3 veces a la semana para abastecer su pulpería; por su carácter amable y jovial se ha ganado la simpatía de sus vecinos y esto le ha servido para tener mayores clientes 
Se siete satisfecha con los servicios brindados por adim, lo que la hace ser fiel con la institución
Su mayor sueño es ampliar su casa para ubicar aparte su negocio y darles mejores condiciones de vida a sus hijos, por tal motivo ella esta ahorrando de sus ganancias para no descapitalizar su negocio
texts.en:
Malasia started her business as soon as her husband became unemployed. With his severance they put up a small general store seeing as their visit at the ADIM offices went well and the requested their first loan, which they invested in the purchase of staple goods. After providing the loan, ADIM invited them to participate in the training workshops, which they came to and participated in-applying what they learned to their business. Malasia goes to the market 3 times a week to supply her store. Because of her kind and jovial personality, she has earned the friendship of her neighbors and they have come to be her best clients. She feels satisfied with the services provided by ADIM, which has made her loyal to the institution. Her greatest dream is to improve her home with a separate space for her business and to provide better living conditions to her children. For this reason she is saving her income so that she will not under-invest in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business Captial; To Grow her business and improve her living conditions.

loans.name: Muheza Group

texts.en:
Lydia M., age 46, is married with four children; ages 25, 22, 20 and 18. She has a mama lishe (café) where she sells all types of foods and cold drinks. She has been in this business since 2003 and works daily from 6am until 10pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of about $152. 

This will be Lydia’s fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous four loans to increase her food stocks.  She has paid the loans back successfully. Lydia now hopes for a new loan to buy more stock of cold drinks. 

Lydia will share this loan with subgroup A of the Muheza group. The subgroup has 7 members, who run shops, sell clothes, cold drinks and own salons. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Lydia is 1st on the right, in a green dress.

loans.use: To increase stock of cold drinks.

loans.name: Tatu N.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 36 years old Tatu M. from Mbeya. She is married with three children who are between the ages of three and 10. 

Tatu has been running a business selling used clothes since 1997. Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers. These retailers then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because of their low cost. Furthermore, western or modern clothing is becoming more appealing Some argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress, however the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

She works at the business for nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee and one family member. Tatu currently earns about 60USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 375USD in order to purchase more used clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of clothes and to open another business. Tatu thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes in bulk

loans.name: Fuente De Bendicion 1&2 Group

texts.en:
The Fuente de Bendicion Bank of Hope from San Pedro de Macoris is starting their entrepreneurship with their first loan from Esperanza International. Joselania S. and Maria G. are the two group coordinators. Joselania is the mother of 5 children between the ages of 16 and 7, and Maria has a 6-year-old son. Joselania has a clothing sales business, and Maria has a vegetable stand. Both will use their loans to buy new products for their customers. They find their daily work is their biggest challenge, but they also believe having their own businesses will allow them to take better care of their children by being self-employed and generating income to provide for their needs. When asked about their dreams for the future, Joselania answered she would like to own a large boutique. Maria want to have her own grocery store and a house of her own. 
Please support these entrepreneurs as they start their businesses thanks to this loan. 
Thank you!

loans.use: Purchase new merchandise

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhon Chum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan consists of eight people located in Sramaoch Haer village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Sokhon C. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which to cultivate rice to earn a living. Aside from owning this plantation, she is a weaver. In her weaving business, she now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy raw material to weave for her customers. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan to enable her to buy it. Mrs. Sokhon C. is a 52-year-old widow with two children who are both employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy raw material to weave for her customers

loans.name: Sun's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan for three women who live in Battambang Province, Cambodia. 

Mrs. Sun S., age 30, has been selected to be group leader by the other members. She is a widowed mother who has two children who are still young and enrolled in school. Her mother, also a widow, lives with her and helps support the family by selling a kind of Khmer sweet. 

S. currently earns an income by selling different kinds of fruits in the local market. She has operated her business for a year. She usually buys her produce from a wholesale supplier and the farmers in bulk and sells them at retail to gain income. S. would like a loan to accrue stock of fruit to sell. 

The other two borrowers are:

C., who sells fish in the market and requests a loan to buy more fish for sale.

V., a vegetable seller seeking a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To accrue stock of fruit to sell

loans.name: Zulfiniso

texts.ru: Хошимова Зулфинисо- женщина 52 лет. Замужем мать 4-х детей. Зулфинисо занимается переработкой пряжи и вышиванием разных шерстенных вещей. Ей помогает в этом невестка и дочка. Муж работает в колхозе она сама также колхозница. В сезон сбора хлопка они всей семьёю выходят на поле и от собранного урожая получают деньги. Зулфинисо также откормом скота у себя дома. Зулфинисо получив займ хочет оптом закупить пряжу с последующей переработкой . Зулфинисо свой товар реализует на рынках Оппон и Булок.
texts.en:
Zulfiniso H. is 52 years old, married and has four children. Zulfiniso is involved in yarn processing and embroidery of various wool items. Her daughter-in-law and daughter help her with the business. Zulfiniso’s husband works at a collective farm. Zulfiniso is also a farmer. During the cotton picking season, their whole family goes out to the field and makes money from the harvest. Zulfiniso is also involved in livestock feeding at home. She wants to use this loan in order to buy processed yarn at a wholesale price. Zulfiniso sells her goods at the Oppon and Bulok markets.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of yarn

loans.name: Pelessi

texts.fr: Pelessi K. est un jeune homme de 35 ans, marié et père de 2 enfants. il est conducteur de taxi moto à Wome depuis 3 ans. Cette activité est sa principale source de revenus.  Sa bonne gestion lui a permis de rembourser rapidement son crédit. Elle désire contracter un nouveau prêt afin d’acquérir une nouvelle moto. il souhaite passer la première à son petit frère. Cette chance leur permettra de changer les conditions de vie de leur famille.
texts.en:
Pelessi K. is a young man, 35 years old, married, and the father of two. He has been a moto taxi driver in Wome for three years. This work is his main source of revenues. Good managing on his part enables him to repay his loan quickly. He would like to take out a new loan in order to acquire a new moto. He wishes to give the first one to his younger brother. This chance will enable them to alter their family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for use as a taxi

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sitha C., 55, and her husband, Mr. Deth Sam, 56, live on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1980 and have two daughters. One of the daughters is married and lives outside the family home and the other one is a garment factory worker.
 
Her husband has been a house builder for five years; it’s a skill he learned from his master. He works in his village.

Sitha has been selling vegetables and pork in front of her house for two years. She hopes to expand her business, so she is asking for her first loan of $250 to purchase more vegetables and pork for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables and pork for resale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort A. is 38 years old. She is married and has given birth to seven children, two sons and three daughters. All are currently in the junior high and the primary schools. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Dwenase in the Western Region. Dwenase is a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso, the district capital. Her husband is a farmer. Comfort is a food vendor. She prepares and sells groundnut toffees. She sells on a tabletop by the roadside from morning to evening. Comfort wants a loan to buy bags of groundnuts and other ingredients such as sugar in bulk. She buys her goods from Kumasi. She has been in business for twelve years. She aspires to expand her business and give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Ganna

texts.en:
Ganna is married with four grown children: a son, three daughters and six grandkids. Her whole family lives in Nadvirna, Western Ukraine. She offers various goods for sale. Ganna owns two vending kiosks at two different local markets – central marketplace and farming supply market. Moreover, she has just bought a small store in a village to offer fresh produce to residents of that neighborhood. Ganna started small about 20 years ago. She worked hard to keep her business running. Lending services have helped her grow and expand her small venture. Currently, Ganna has about 30,000 Grivnyas in the vending business. Her net monthly profit is about 6,000 Grivnyas.  

Ganna is requesting a loan of 16,000 Grivnyas to purchase mineral fertilizer wholesale for further retail sale at one of her vending locations. She has much experience working in the sphere of trade and commerce for over 37 years. After Ganna retired, she ventured to launch her small vending business and hasn’t been sorry about it. Today her business is the main source of income for her family and kids. 

On the photo, Ganna is pictured at one of her vending locations where she offers clothing items for retail sale.

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizer

loans.name: God Is Great Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 35 years old and a divorced mother of two kids. The children are currently in school. She is a petty trader who trades in used clothes and has been in business for the past three years. Used clothing has a very big market in Ghana as brand-new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore, the selling of used clothing has created opportunities for many women like Elizabeth. 

She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her save for her children's education and for renting a store as she now sells through hawking.

She is the leader of a trust bank group called "God is great." She is the one sitting in front in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and/or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and as peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria is 45 years old. She sells rice in the village of San Ignacio, Ilagan, Isabela. She also sells aluminum stoves that her husband assembles. With these businesses, Candelaria generates enough income to sustain the daily needs of their family.  

Candelaria wishes that her business will improve and, hopefully, will be known by others, especially her aluminum stove business.  To become more productive in the business, Candelaria is seeking financial support from Kiva lenders. She would like to borrow PHP 10,000. She also believes that having this amount will make her business grow more and will support the education of their children.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Yolanda  es socia del Banco Comunal Desarrollo.
Yolanda es casada, tiene 36 años y 5 hijos, Yolanda vende verduras en el mercado Nery García, ella compra de los productores y lo vende al por mayor, actividad que realiza desde las 1 de la mañana hasta las 7 de la mañana. Además tiene un mototaxi que alquila.
Yolanda necesita un préstamo de 800 soles dinero que será invertido en la reparación de la mototaxi.
Los sueños de Yolanda son construir su casa y educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Yolanda is a member of the Desarrollo Microfinance Institute.

Yolanda is a 36-year-old married mother with 5 children. Yolanda sells vegetables at the Nery García market. She buys the produce from growers and sells it wholesale from 1 to 7 in the morning. Additionally, she owns a motorcycle taxi that she rents out.

Yolanda needs an 800.00 PEN loan, which will be invested in repairing her motorcycle taxi.

Yolanda dreams of building her house and of providing her children with an education so that they can one day become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
R. Jamila is 44 years old. She and her husband-cook have three children of school age. Already for 17 years she is selling the clothing and footwear for kids. The income from the business Jamila is spending for educating of her children as she and her husband are dreaming that their children will have the higher education. Jamila has been provided with the loans by IMON almost for 3 years. For the entire period of time she has shown herself as an accurate client. Today she requests $800 US for purchasing new goods for selling. Jamila promises to pay the loan in time and thanks all supporting her.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of new goods for selling in order to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: La Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.en:
Maria is a 49-year-old borrower who lives near San Pedro D. Macorís, Dominican Republic. Maria is a coordinator for her group, La Nueva Esperanza (The New Hope), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Maria has six children, and all but one have moved out of her home. Along with her youngest, a 15-year-old, Maria cares for a local 18-year-old girl who has a child of her own. Two of her children are currently studying in towns around the Dominican Republic, and the others now have families of their own. Maria lives in a batey called L. Blocks. Bateyes are communities built by sugar companies for their workers, and are usually very humble accommodations. Life in a batey can be harsh; they are difficult to access, receive no running water, lack sufficient sanitation, and have little to no electricity. 

Despite these difficulties, Maria runs a successful business selling vehicle necessities, including spare tires, oil, and gasoline. Maria also hopes to expand her business by selling prepaid cell-phone cards. Both her auto supplies and her cell-phone cards help the community have better access to the outsiD. world, and both are in high demand.

This is Maria’s sixth loan with Esperanza, and she has been a hard-working borrower for over three years. She hopes that with success will come a legacy she can pass on to her children, and that someday they can have a better life than she experienced. Thank you for your loan to Maria and La Nueva Esperanza group!

loans.use: Spare tires, gas, oil, and phone cards

loans.name: Mahussi Victoire

texts.fr: K. Mahussi Victoire est née en 1981. Victoire est mariée à ATCHOU Pierre. Victoire et Pierre ont trois enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge dont deux sont les leurs. La famille vit à Djassin à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative du Bénin. Victoire et Pierre assurent ensemble les charges de la famille. C’est du gasoil que Victoire vend à domicile. Victoire va s’approvisionner en gasoil au Nigeria, État voisin du Bénin. Victoire ne dispose pas de moyens financiers suffisants pour couvrir la demande de sa clientèle. Alors, Victoire sollicite ce prêt de ALIDé pour mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
K. Mahussi Victoire was born in 1981.  She is married to ATCHOU Pierre.  She and Pierre support three children who are all in school. Two of the children are theirs. The family lives in Djassin in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of the Republic of Benin.  Victoire and Pierre together ensure that family expenses are covered.  Victoire sells diesel fuel at home.  To stock up on it, she goes to Nigeria, a country neighboring Benin.  She lacks sufficient financial means to meet customer demands.  And so she's requesting this ALIDé loan, as to be more responsive to them.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy containers of fuel oil

loans.name: Mujeres Vencedoras Group

texts.es: El Banco Comunal denominado  MUJERES VENCEDORAS está conformado por trece personas D. edades variadas que oscilan desD. los 20 a los 50 años. La presidenta es madre D. tres hijos uno D. ellos ya conformo su familia y los otros son adolecentes, La Sra. Juana tesorera D. la banca en una persona muy alegre y proactiva, la Sra. Nora secretaria D. la banca es una persona con carácter fuerte y proactivo las otras personas que conforman la banca tienen personalidades similares. La presidenta la Sra. Yolanda se dedica a la administración D. una pequeña tienda D. barrio y a la distribución D. cerveza, la Sra. Juana  se dedica a la artesanía en lana como ser prendas D. vestir y otros productos que los realiza en su domicilio. La Sra. Nora también se dedica a la artesanía en lana como algunas D. las socias que con las cuales comparten esta actividad, otras  socias D. dedican a la venta D. ropa deportiva, para mujeres, para niños, la Sra. Lourdes se dedica a la venta D. muñecos D. peluche, otra D. las socias a la venta sal en las ferias D. la zona, también hay otras socias que se dedica a la elaboración D. joyas tanto en oro como en plata. Si bien dentro D. los lugares donD. se desarrollan sus actividades existen otros similares, la afluencia D.  consumidores a los mercados, y el constante crecimiento urbano  hace que las actividades que se desarrollen en el lugar no se vean afectadas por lo contrario muchas D. las socias están esperanzadas en hacer crecer sus negocios ampliándolos por lo cual solicitan el crédito. Las socias solicitan  el crédito para realizar la adquisición D. mercadería en mayor cantidad, otras para la compra D. materiales D. construcción  para el ampliado D. sus pequeños locales y dar mejor atención a sus clientes otras para la compra D. materia prima y D. esta manera incrementar su capital D. trabajo. Este grupo se encuentra en su segundo ciclo, por lo cual  la mayoría D. ellas ya se conocen entre sí y cuentan con experiencia D. trabajo en esta modalidad D. crédito.
texts.en:
The community bank called Mujeres Vencedoras consists of 13 people of a variety of ages that range from 20 to 50 years old. The president is a mother of 3 children, one of which is already settled with his own family and the others are adolescents. Juana is the treasurer of the bank and is a very cheerful and proactive person. Nora is the secretary of the bank and has a strong and proactive character. The other people that belong to the bank have similar personalities. The president, Yolanda, runs a small neighborhood store and a beer distribution business. Juana works in her home crafting wool garments and other products. Nora also works in the crafting of wool, along with some of the other members who share this activity. Other members work selling sports clothing for women and children. Lourdes works selling stuffed animals. Others work selling salt at the open markets in the area. There are also members who work making jewelry from gold and silver. While there are other similar businesses in the area where the members are developing their businesses, the influx of consumer markets and the continued urban growth make it so that the development of their activities is not adversely affected; on the contrary many members are hoping to grow and extend their businesses which is why they are asking for a loan. The members are asking for credit to be able to buy goods in greater quantities; others to buy materials for construction to enlarge their small shops and to give better service to their customers; other to buy raw materials to increase their working capital. This group is in their second loan cycle and so most of them already know each other and have experience working with this type of loan.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise and raw materiales

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda A. is a 40- year old businesswoman from Baseco Compound, Port Area, Manila. She is married to Rodelito, 47, a welder/pipe fitter. They have four kids of whom two are in high school and one in grade school.

Imelda has a sari-sari (general) store located just in front of her house. In front of the store, she also sells cooked foods. She has been enjoying her business for almost 20 years now and earns 21,000 PHP a month.

Imelda joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2004.

She has applied for a new loan in the amount of 18,000 PHP. She will buy more items to sell at her store to include soft drinks and rice.

She wants to see her general store to be bigger in the future than what it is now so she could help employ some of her neighbors. She also dreams of opening a restaurant soon. She also wishes to see all her children finishing their studies.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell including softdrinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying bananas, plantains, and oranges

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati is 36 years old. She is divorced and has two children who are both in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community in the central region of Ghana. Fati is a trader. She trades in secondhand footwear, dress bags, head gear and heats, etc. She hawks and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. Fati has been in business for seven years and desires to give her business a facelift. She therefore wants the loan to procure goods in bulk to be able to achieve this dream.

loans.use: To buy footwear, headwear, etc. for resale

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: L. Emmanuel is a 48-year-old businessman. He is the father of four children. He has a charcoal business which he started five years ago, and a poultry farm in his area. He is using the loan to stock more bags of charcoal to expand his business. He has some rental houses. His aim is to renovate the houses and educate his children.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to expand his business.

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es:
Maritza, de 19 años, es una joven soltera muy alegre y trabajadora, vive en la casa de sus padres a quienes desea ayudar con los gastos del hogar.
Aunque todavía es muy joven está decidida a trabajar muy duro para ya no depender de sus padres, puesto que siente que es hora de sobresalir por sí misma. Para ello realiza tejidos artesanales, los cuales lleva a vender a su puesto de venta ubicado en la Explanada Laguna Temporal (lugar donde se realizan ferias en Juliaca).
A su vez, lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es tejer y más aun si son artesanías; lleva 2 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es trasladar los tejidos hasta su puesto de venta, ya que le resulta muy cansado.
Para más adelante, espera tener una tienda muy grande de ropa tejida a mano, en la cual pueda vender con más tranquilidad y atender mejor a sus clientes.

Este es el tercer préstamo de Maritza con MFP, ella ha sido muy puntual en sus pagos y nunca ha tenido problemas con su banco comunal, donde es la encargada de poner la cuota de alegría que mantiene a las demás socias muy contentas. Con los tres mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará mejores materiales para elaborar más tejidos artesanales y así incrementar la cantidad que tiene en stock.
texts.en:
19-year-old Maritza is a young, single woman who is very happy and hardworking. She lives in her parents' home, and wishes to help them with their household expenses. Although she is still very young, she has decided to work very hard so she doesn't have to depend on her parents; she feels it is time for her to get herself ahead. In order to do this, she makes woven handicrafts, which she sells from a booth in Explanada Laguna Temporal [Seasonal Lagoon Esplanade], a fair location in Juliaca. What she likes most about her job is weaving and making handicrafts. She has been doing this for two years, and she considers transporting the handicrafts to the sales point to be the most difficult part, as it makes her very tired. In the future, she hopes to have a large store for handmade clothing, where she can sell in a more relaxed manner and give better attention to her customers. This is Maritza's third loan with MFP. She has been very punctual in her payments and has never had problems with her communal bank, where she spreads joy that keeps the other members happy. With this loan of 3,000 soles, she will buy better materials to make more woven goods and increase the quantity she has in stock.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials for woven handicrafts

loans.name: Ceferina

texts.en:
Cerefina A. is a resident of Quisao, Tanay, Rizal. She is 68 years old and single. As she is reaching an older age, she is working hard on her own. She is grateful that they have an ASHI group in their village that offers her happiness and so she never feels alone in achieving her goals in life.

Currently, Ceferina is busy with her small business of buying and selling RTW (Ready To Wear) clothes just to earn the means to live every day. When she received a small amount of capital from ASHI, she managed to put it all into her business. For her, business is an important factor and she does not want to be a problem for her group mates or for the center.

She applied for a new loan amount of PHP 20,000.00 to have additional working capital for her RTW business. Specifically the loan funds will be used to buy more stock like pairs of sandals, slippers, and accessories (for all ages).

Ceferina is a very good member of ASHI. She performs well in her business; when she has enough capital, she adds more business in order to gain more income. She hopes to share this with her sister, Paulita, who is a 55 year old maid. 

She hopes that through her loans from ASHI, in partnership with KIVA, that someday she will be able to save money for her future use because she is getting older now.

loans.use: Buy more stock like pairs of sandals, slippers and accessories.

loans.name: Nhek

texts.en:
Nhek S., age 52, is widowed and resides with her children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has six children. She sells vegetables and fruits, earning approximately US $7.00 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family's expenses, especially her children’s education. She has been in this business since 1981. The family is also assisted by her three children who work at different workplace to support the family. Their standard of living has been improved since S. started her business, so she wants a loan to expand her business. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD $700 to purchase more vegetables and fruits to sell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner. 

S. and her daughter appear in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Kigo Namatovu Jesica Group

texts.en: Jesica N. is a hardworking 31-year-old businesswoman, married with four children attending school and taking care of two additional dependents also attending school. She has operated her retail shop for over four years and will use the loan to purchase retail shop items such as sugar, salt, soap, rice, cooking oil, etc. Jessica's dream is to improve upon the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To purchase retail shop items such as sugar, salt, soap, rice, cooking oil, and so forth.

loans.name: Luisa Isabel

texts.es:
La señora luisa C. se levanta de horas tempranas para elaborar los diferentes sabores de refresco para luego trasladarse a su puesto de venta en el mercado central finalizando a las 4:00 pm.

Este crédito que solicito es  para  incrementar su negocio en  la compra de más golosinas como: galletas, caramelos, meneítos, gaseosas, bolsas de agua,   y otros.
texts.en:
Luisa C. gets up early in the morning to start preparing different flavors of refreshments. Later, she goes to her vending post in the central market where she sells the refreshments until 4:00pm. She is requesting a loan in order to expand her business. She would like to purchase more snacks such as cookies, candy, cheese puffs as wells as soft drinks, plastic bags of water, and other staples.

Translated from Spanish by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cookies, candy, soft drinks, different sweets, and plastic bags of water

loans.name: Lapaz Tb Group

texts.en:
Esther A. describes herself as hard-working, a woman for whom no challenge is too great. She is 30 years old and is the leader of the 'Lapaz' borrower group. Esther lives in Safwi and bakes bread. She has been baking bread for 7 years. Esther is excited to be taking out this loan, which she will use to purchase three bags of flour, one bag of sugar and two packs of margarine. 

She wants to use the extra profits she anticipates as a result of this loan to buy a plot of land to start building accommodation for her family. 

She is married to a commercial driver and together they have three children. Esther hopes to make more savings to be able to provide good education for all of her children, hopefully through University level. 

Esther is currently the leader of the trust bank group called Lapaz, made up of seven members. The other members are engaged in businesses such as food selling, hair dressing, grocery sales, used clothes sales, etc. They are the major breadwinners of their respective families and are looking for this loan to support their business and eventually raise more income to support their families.

loans.use: To purchase baking ingredients.

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina O. is a 74 year-old widow who supports her family with a general store, an eatery, a cafeteria, and a sugarcane farm business. She lives in Brgy. Tapi, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She has nine children between 35 and 42 -- most of them married with their own families.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 30,000.

Florentina is now borrowing Php 23,000 so that she can continue her general store, eatery, cafeteria and farm businesses. This will be her 18th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 20,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Florentina aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieve realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -- a title of esteem bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more sugar, yeast, flour and milk.

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr: Née en 1973 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, D. Elisabeth est mariée à AKPLOGAN Thomas, un chauffeur. Le couple a six enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais un des enfants n'est plus à leur charge. Elisabeth vit avec sa famille à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis neuf ans. Elisabeth apporte une aide à son mari en assurant avec lui les différentes charges familiales. Elisabeth n'a pas été à l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Elisabeth prépare et vend de la nourriture ("akassa" fait à base d'amidon de maïs, riz, accompagné de sauce aux poissons et de viande) à son domicile. Elisabeth se ravitaille à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Elisabeth exerce cette activité depuis douze ans environs. C'est la première fois que Elisabeth sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, afin de renforcer son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, Elisabeth D. is married to Thomas Akplogan, a driver. The couple has six children, all of whom are educated. One of the children is no longer under the couple's care. Elizabeth has lived with her family in Ekpè, in the community of Sèmè-Podji, for nine years. Elisabeth helps her husband to assure that their family's needs are met. Elisabeth did not go to school. To meet her needs, Elisabeth prepares and sells food ("akassa" made from a maize starch base, and rice with fish and meat) from her home. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Elisabeth has done this work for about twelve years. This is the first time Elisabeth is asking for a loan from ALIDé in order to strengthen her business and better meet the demand of her clientele.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of maize, fish, rice, meat and condiments

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
K. Gloria, a trained midwife, has been providing medical services to her clients, especially mothers in labor, for four years in Kasule, Mubende. Here in Uganda one of the common medical problems faced is that there are very few health facilities to cater to the sick. Thus very many women here die on giving birth due to inadequate services.

Gloria’s main problem is not having enough space to deliver health services to the many patients who visit her medical clinic. With this loan, she is looking at putting into execution her plan to construct an extension house to support the accommodation of her patients. This will see her earn more revenue.

loans.use: To construct an extension to her health facility

loans.name: Hom

texts.en: A widowed mother, Hom P., 46 years old, resides in the province of Siem Reap. Hom P. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises the pigs both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she cultivates a rice crop. Hom P. has eight children who are all single. Two of her children are employees in a small firm. Hom P. is seeking a Kiva loan to purchase additional pigs to raise. This will provide her with greater profits.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to raise.

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Sourn S., 31, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the favorite tourist place in the country.

S. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a construction worker and earns an income of USD 8 per day. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more construction tools to improve her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more construction tools for her husband's business

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn M. is from the village of Polo Pitogo. She is 20 years old and married. To make a living, Jovelyn raises pigs for sale. She is just starting this business.

In 2010, Jovelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovelyn is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jovelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To extend his field and buy fertilizers

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en: Lenie H. is from the village of Soyung Echague. She is 28 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Lenie owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,500 PHP when she sells a raised animal. In 2010, Lenie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her first from ASKI. Lenie plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy boubou, fabric, and Holland wax

loans.name: Adolf

texts.en:
Adolf M. was born in 1978. He is married to Odette Nyonga and they are blessed with three children and all are below the age of 15 years old. He and the family live in a small house of three rooms. He lives in Nitop III, a quarter in Bamenda North West Region of Cameroon.

Adolf has faced some challenges in life. Amongst which are the inability to meet the basic necessities of his family, like clothing, feeding, transportation and educating himself and his children. It is difficult to raise capital to start up a small business that will sustain him and his family. He plans to invest this loan in a transport business, by buying a motorbike for transporting people and goods from one place to another. He believes the business will succeed because the previous loan he took was repaid by the income raised from an old bike of his, therefore he concludes that he is sure the business will succeed. He is certain that this business will succeed because the roads around the area of residence are poor, therefore the bike is a paramount way of transportation. The loan will help his community because they will be able to afford a considerable means of transport at cheaper fares. 

Adolf will plough back his profit into his business and use part to care for his family. He also will use the proceeds to pay his children’s school fees and cater for the family. He prefers GHAPE because of the training he frequently receives and the low cost in obtaining and paying back a loan.

About GHAPE 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en:
Chhorn M., 45, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia – an area known for rubber plantations. M. and her husband raise and sell fish, earning about $15 US per day. The family has to spend $50 US on food, $20 US on children's education, and $15 US on other necessary expenses every month.

M. is requesting a loan of $500 US to purchase more fish to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando P. is from the village of Binakalan, Gingoog City. He is 41 years old. Fernando is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Fernando owns and operates a retail store, buying and selling coconuts and bananas in the local community. Fernando has been engaged in his business for more than a year and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Fernando joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Fernando has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Fernando is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which he will use to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be his second loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Cerila

texts.en:
Cerila B. is from the village of Sampagar, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Cerila is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Cerila owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, instant noodles, and snack foods in the local community. Cerila has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cerila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Cerila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Cerila is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Cerila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: María Cristina

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal María Monserrate se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

La señora María es socia del Banco Comunal desde sus inicios y esta muy contenta en el ya que gracias a los créditos recibidos de parte de la Fundación Espoir ha logrado sacar su negocio adelante. Tiene 53 años de edad, esta casada y fruto de esta relación tiene cuatro hijos todos mayores pero dos de ellos aun viven con ella. Su marido es comerciante.

Ella se dedica al comercio, tiene un local donde  vende juguetes, bisutería y reliquias las mismas que son muy apreciadas por los visitantes que a diario se hacen presentes en el cantón por ser un lugar muy tradicional, trabaja todos los días desde las 10am hasta las 16h00, algunos de sus productos los compra en Guayaquil y otros a artesanos de la localidad.

Este crédito es para comprar más mercadería como: juguetes, bisutería y reliquias para surtir aun mas su negocio. Su sueño es tener un gran local.
texts.en:
The community bank named Maria Monserrate meets every two weeks in the district of Montecristi, a region known for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its nationally and internationally renowned artisans. This is the region from where the famous straw hats originate.

Maria has been a member of this community bank since its inception and she is very happy to take part especially for the loans she has received. Fundacion Espoir (Kiva Field Partner) has given her the ability to find success with her business. She is 53 years old, she is married, and they have four grown children, although two are still living with her. Her husband is a merchant. 

She is a merchant who sells toys, jewelry and other objects. Her merchandise is sought out by visitors who come to the district every day. The region is a very traditional place. She works there every day from 10 a.m. to 4p.m. She purchases some of her merchandise from Guayaquil and from other artisans in the region. 

Her loan will be used to purchase merchandise such as toys, jewelry and souvenirs to resupply her business. Her dream is to have a large store.

loans.use: To purchase toys, jewerly and souvenirs.

loans.name: Artemia

texts.es: Artemia, D. 52 años, está casada con Lucio, D. 60 años. Ambos tienen 8 hijos, pero solo viven con 4 D. ellos, a los que cuida y educa en su casa propia, ubicada en la localidad D. Ricrican. Los días D. Artemia, son inspiradores, pues está hermosa mujer, todos los días desD. las primeras horas D. la mañana sale a cuidar a sus corderos, gallinas y cuyes, a los que alimenta para engordarlos y luego comercializarlos a un mayor precio. Ella tiene 40 años dedicándose a la agricultura, donD. también siembra tubérculos como: papa, olluco y oca; “toda una vida”, y según afirma, está acostumbrada a la vida del campo, su mayor deseo es morir entre las hermosas praderas verdes D. sus sembríos. Pero como aún tiene hijos menores, ella está pensando acondicionar un pequeño espacio en su casa, donD. venderá verduras y hortalizas. Este es el  séptimo crédito con MFP, y como socia activa D. su banco comunal, aporta ideas y sugerencias para el progreso D. su banco. Con el monto que solicita comprará, 15 sacos D. abono orgánico, los que esparcirá en todos sus sembríos, los que muy pronto cosechará.
texts.en:
Artemia is 52 years old.  She is married to 60 year-old Lucio.  They have 8 children but live with only 4 of them, who they care for and educate in their own home which is located in the town of Ricrican.

Artemia's days are inspiring.  This beautiful woman gets up early in the morning every day to go and care for her lambs, hens and guinea pigs.  She feeds her animals, fattens them and then sells them at a higher price.  She has been in the farming business for 40 years.  She also grows root vegetables such as potatoes, 'olluco' (a native tuber) and 'oca' (a native tuber).  She has been doing this for “an entire lifetime” and she says that she is used to the country life.  Her biggest desire is to die amongst the beautiful green fields of her crops.  However, as Artemia still has young children, she is thinking of adapting a small space in her house from which she can sell greens and vegetables.

This is Artemia's seventh loan with MFP and, as an active member of her community bank, she brings ideas and suggestions to her bank which help it to make progress.  She will use her loan to buy 15 sacks of organic fertilizer which she will spread over her crops that she will harvest very soon.

loans.use: To buy 15 sacks of organic fertilizer

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose L. is from the town of Banga. She is 48 years old and married. To make a living, she plants and harvests corn for sale. She has been engaged in farming for over 28 years.

Rose joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: María De Lourdes

texts.es:
La señora María de Lourdes M., trabaja en la Universidad Nacional de Ingeniería (UNI), ubicada en la oficina de servicios administrativos, tiene 18 años de laborar como cocinera.
Es casada madre de dos hijos que todavía estudian, ella ya ha pagado 6 créditos en CEPRODEL, los que han pagado puntualmente, los ha utilizado para construcción de su vivienda. Este crédito lo quiere para construir una parte de su vivienda
texts.en: Mrs. María de Lourdes M. works at the National University of Engineering, in the office of administrative services.  She has worked as a cook for 18 years.  Mrs. M. is married with two children, who currently attend school.  She has already punctually paid off 6 loans with CEPRODEL.  She has used the loans to construct her home.  She is requesting another loan to continue the construction of her home.

loans.use: Home Construction

loans.name: Jean Aime

texts.fr:
Âgé de 30 ans, handicapé partiel et étudiant en  année de licence, il  a une petite boutique d’alimentation  au campus pour aider ses amis étudiants à  ne pas s’éloigner pour leurs petits achats.

Ses revenus par jour avant le premier prêt étaient de 10.000f, après  elles ont augmentes de 25000f par jour, il sait maintenant avec la formation que HOPE lui a  donné en ce qui concerne l'étude DE faisabilité, le journal de caisse il peut contrôler son stock, connaître quelle genre de  marchandise acheté pour accroitre ses revenus. 

Sa stratégie est d’ouvrir tôt pour être fidèle à sa clientèle, modérer les prix de ventes, faire des petites soldes par rapports au pouvoir d’achat des étudiants et enfin offrir un bon l’accueil.
Avec le prochain prêt, il veut agrandir et ouvrir une grande boutique et a aussi a l'intention d'ouvrir une crèmerie . 
Il a  pour objectif de soutenir  ses frères et sœurs a faire des longues études.
texts.en:
30 years of age, partially disabled and in his last year of undergraduate studies, he keeps a small grocery store on campus, in order to allow his fellow students to make all their everyday purchases without having to go far. 

His daily sales before the first loan were 10,000 West African francs, and later they have gone up to 25,000 francs. Thanks to the training and the feasibility study provided by HOPE, he now knows how to keep a cash register and track his inventory, and  understands what type of goods are better to purchase so as to  increase his revenues. 

His strategy is to open at an early hour in order to be always there for his customers, to keep the prices low, to offer some promotions in view of the students’ purchasing power, and offer friendly service. With his next loan, he would like to expand his business and open a larger shop. He would also like to open a milk products shop. His goal is to support brothers and sisters in their higher education studies.

loans.use: Purchasing boxes of milk, butter, margarine, sugar, canned food etc

loans.name: Koem's Group

texts.en:
There are twelve members forming this village bank loan, all of whom live in Tep Archun village in Kandal province. Mrs. Koem N. was born in 1965 and  has been selected to be the village bank president by the other members.

Her husband, Mr. Phorn Chok, is a fisherman who is able to earn a small income to help support his family. This couple has five children.  Four are students in the local school and also support their mother with farming, while the youngest one is 5 years old and not in school yet.

Mrs. Koem N. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows rice. In order to support this farming, she would like a loan to buy fertilizers and gasoline to support her crop.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and gasoline to support her farming crop.

loans.name: Baindu

texts.en:
This is 47 year-old Baindu.  She is married and has 5 children ages 20,17,15,11 and 8 years old.  She has 3 additional dependents who live with her because they are her family members from the provinces where educational facilities are poor.  

In 1999, Baindu established her restaurant business.  She began her business after the war as a means of generating income for their livelihood.  Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she earns about 1,216,400 SLL every month from this business.  She would like a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 SLL.  Baindu needs a new loan to help her buy rice and other ingredients in large quantities.  She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 242,880 SLL.  In the future, Baindu plans to get another restaurant.   She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy additional food items.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a married woman with three school-going children. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has owned real estate houses for the past 10 years; her potential customers are tenants and local residents. In addition she also sells handbags which contributes to her income. Joyce faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing permanent rental houses in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to pay school fees for her child. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to uplift her living standard.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her child

loans.name: Sochul

texts.en:
Mrs. Sochul was born in 1984. She is a married woman who has three children, one of whom is attending a local public school, while the others are too young to work or study. 

She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she can grow rice. She sells part of the rice and the rest is for her family. Besides farming, she is also a chicken breeder. Her husband, Mr. Ten, is a laborer. 

In order to improve her family’s income, she wants to start a new business, but she does not have enough money to support it. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Sochul is asking for a loan to buy two piglets for breeding.

loans.use: to buy two piglets for breeding

loans.name: Kangombe

texts.en:
Kangombe is a married woman with nine children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity, nor piped water.  

For the past three years, she has operated a fish-selling business. Kangombe faces a major challenge of high transportation costs in her business. She dreams of opening more businesses in the future. With the KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of fish and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fish and cooking oil.

loans.name: Celia Jannet

texts.es:
Celia de 35 años, es una mujer trabajadora que empezó su actividad hace dos por iniciativa de sus hijas antes de que empezara su negocio trabajaba en empresa de producción pero como no le daba tiempo as sus hijas comenzó su negocio vendiendo ropa puerta a puerta.

Actualmente tiene un puesto de ropa y artículos varios en el malecón de playas ella lo abre en temporadas todos los días, pero después solo de jueves a domingos y de lunes a miércoles recorre con su mercadería y sus hijas la ayuda en el negocio. Con la ayuda del prestamos quiere comprar mas mercadería como ropa , interiores, pantalones de mujer. Lo que mas anhela es comprarse un carro aunque sea de asegunda mano ya que se le hace difícil transportar mercadería, tener un local mas grande.
texts.en:
Celia is 35 years old and she is a hardworking woman who started her business two years ago following her daughters' initiative. Prior to this she worked in a production company but she couldn't spend time with her daughters. So she started selling clothing from door to door. 

Today she has a clothing stand and she also sells various articles in the community of Playa. She opens her business every day during the high season, but later she only opens from Thursdays to Sundays. From Mondays to Wednesdays she travels with her merchandise and her daughters help her with the business. With the help of this loan she wants to purchase more clothing merchandise, undergarments, and ladies' slacks. Her greatest goal is to purchase a car, even if it is a used car, as it is difficult to transport her merchandise. She also wants to have a larger store.

loans.use: to purchase ladies' clothing for resale.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy more fish to sell. Vivian has been in this business for 4 years. She earns additional income from food vending.

Vivian has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money in order to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Samira

texts.ru: Samira yavlyayetsya IDP personom, ona pereselenec iz Khodjali , seychas projivayet v Absheron regione vmeste so svoyey sestroy. Samira 31 qod. Ona ne zamujem i ne imeyet detey. Ona uje 3 qoda kak zanimayetsya prodajey jenskoy kosmeticheskoy produkcii kak kraski dlya volos, maski dlya licca, shampuni, kremi i t. d. Samira nujdayetsya v 2300 AZN chtobi kupit novuyu kosmeticheskuyu produkciyu dlya pereprodaji i razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa.
texts.en: Samira is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person).  She is a refugee from Khodjali who now lives in the Absheron region with her sister.  Samira is 31 years old.  She is not married and has no children.  For three years, she has been selling cosmetics like hair dye, facial masks, shampoo, creams, etc.  Samira needs 2300 AZN to buy new cosmetics for resale and to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy new cosmetics for resale

loans.name: San Jose Group

texts.es:
El banco Comunal San José, inicia su ciclo 7 con 16 socias, las cuales tienen diversos negocios como la venta D. salchipapas, comidas, verduras, queso, ropa, leña, abarrotes.
Graciela es la Presidenta del Banco Comunal por tercera vez, es madre soltera con 4 hijos, se dedica a la venta D. salchipapas, el préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra D. latas D. aceite, mostaza, sacos D. papa, platos descartables, pollos, etc.
Le gusta Finca Perú, por la facilidad en los préstamos pasa momentos gratos con sus compañeras D. Banco. Está ahorrando para comprarse un terreno. Su sueño es que sus hijos sean profesionales que tengan mejores oportunidades que ella y que su negocio siga prosperando.
texts.en:
The San Jose Community Bank started its seventh loan cycle with 16 members who have diverse businesses, such as selling salchipapas, meals, vegetables, cheese, clothes, firewood, and groceries.

Graciela is the president of the community bank for her third time. She is a single mother with four children. She sells salchipapas (sausage or hotdogs mixed with french fries and served with condiments). The loan that she is requesting will be used to purchase cans of (cooking) oil, mustard, sacks of potatoes, disposable plates, chicken, etc.

She likes Kiva partner FINCA Peru because of the ease of getting loans. She shares pleasant moments with her friends from the bank. She is saving up to buy a plot of land. Her dream is that her children will become professionals who have better opportunities that she did and that her business will continue to prosper.

loans.use: to purchase oil, mustard, sacks of potatoes, disposable plates, and chicken

loans.name: Dina Brigida

texts.es:
Dina es socia del  Banco Comunal “Virgen de Concepción”, ubicado en el C.P. Ayrumas Carumas del distrito de Acora, provincia y departamento de Puno, tiene 27 años de edad, es   conviviente y tiene 2 hijos.  Estudió hasta 3ro de secundaria. 
Viene  trabajando con el  Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace un año, su primer préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevo soles lo invirtió en su negocio de venta de granos de la Región, engorde de ganados vacunos, también dice que vende comidas rápidas y frutas. Es toda una empresaria.
Con este nuevo préstamo  de S/. 2000.00 Nuevos soles dinero, comprará un toro y también comprará frutas como manzana, plátano, naranjas y peras para su trueque (canje de uno por otro producto).  La señora nos cuenta que también se dedica  a la artesanía, a la fabricación de chalinas, chompas, mantones, manoplas, guantes y títeres.  Ella cuenta con el apoyo y ayuda de su esposo, quien a veces trabaja en la  ciudad de Arequipa.
Su sueño es ser empresaria de artesanías en general y así mejorar sus ingresos.
Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal son las charlas respecto a la convivencia familiar y el manejo del dinero.
texts.en:
Dina is a member of the Virgen de Concepción Bank in the Ayrumas Carumas village, Acora district, Puno province and department.  She is 27 years old, in a common-law marriage, and has two children.  She went to school up to the third year of high school.

She has been working with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for one year.  She used her first loan of 500 soles to invest in her business of selling regional grains and fattening cows.  She says that she also sells fast food and fruit.  She is totally a businesswoman.

She will use this new loan for 2,000 soles to buy a bull.  She will also buy fruits like apples, bananas, oranges, and pears for her exchange (swapping one product for another).

She tells us that she also makes handicrafts.  She makes scarves, sweaters, shawls, mittens, gloves, and puppets.  She has her husband’s help and support.  At times he works in the city of Arequipa.

Her dream is to be a general handicrafts businesswoman.  That would improve her income.  The talks about family life and managing money are what she likes about her communal bank.

loans.use: to buy a bull and to also buy fruit.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 33 years old and has two children. She is married and both her children are in school.

Evelyn is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Evelyn requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Evelyn has been raising pigs for three years now and has borrowed five times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Evelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie is married and has a tailoring business in the Philippines.  She has been in this business for 3 years and works hard to support her family. 

Lanie has requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to buy materials for her tailoring business.  In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: buy materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Akovi

texts.fr:
Akovi est un homme âgé de 37 ans. Il est marié à une couturière. Il a 01 enfant 
Akovi travaille comme frigoriste depuis 2000. Il sert ses  clients à BE KPOTA. Il achète les produits à LOME. Il travaille avec 01 employé. 
Akovi a requis son quatrième cycle de prêt à WAGES afin d’acheter des compresseurs.
texts.en:
Akovi, 37, is married to a seamstress and has one child. 
 
Akovi has been working in refrigerator repair since 2000. He serves his clients at BE KPOTA. He buys his products in LOME. He works with one employee.
 
Akovi has requested fourth loan through WAGES in order to buy compressors.

loans.use: to buy compressors.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to get a bigger varieties of slippers, so she can meet the demands of her customers.

loans.name: Parachichi Group

texts.en:
Mary, who is in her late-20s, is married with two children and one of them goes to school.  She has had a charcoal business for two years now.  She works from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. 

This will be her second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to buy four sacks of charcoal and pay for household expenses.  She paid back her loan successfully.  She wants a loan to buy more sacks of charcoal.  Her dream is to one day be able to open a retail shop.

She will share this loan with her loan group, "Parachichi," which has a total of 17 members.  They will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Javier

texts.es: El señor Javier, trabaja como mecánico en un taller de reparación de movilidades en la ciudad de La Paz. El crédito lo requiere para la compra de herramientas de trabajo ya que realiza trabajos de mecánica por su cuenta en su tiempo libre y no tiene un taller fijo. Vive en casa de sus padres  ubicada en la zona de San Juan Cotahuma en la ciudad de La Paz;  es soltero  y no tiene hijos. Esta es la segunda vez que solicita ayuda de Kiva para fondeo de este crédito.
texts.en:
Sr. Javier works as a mechanic at a vehicle repair shop in the city of La Paz. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy tools for his work. He performs repair jobs in his spare time and does not have a permanent workshop. Javier lives at home with his parents in the District of San Juan Cotahuma in the city of La Paz. He is single and has no children.

This is the second time that Kiva is being asked to help fund his loan.

loans.use: to purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: Maria De Los Reyes

texts.es:
Maria es un señor de 40 años de edad, el cual vive con su esposo e hijos, en una comunidad llamada el Upala de San Carlos, en la provincia de Alajuela. En Alajuela existen cinco parques nacionales, una reserva nacional de fauna silvestre, cinco zonas protectoras y varias reservas forestales. También en la provincia se ubica el Museo Juan Santamaría, el cual exhibe artesanías producidas localmente. Esta zona ocupa el primer lugar nacional en la producción de café y azúcar de caña.

Desde hace varios años que Maria tiene este negocio de actividad agrícola, ya que cuenta en estos momentos con el propiedad que le heredaron sus padres de aproximadamente ¾ de hectáreas, pero le falta lo principal para que su negocio surja y para que los vecinos de su comunidad se vean beneficiados. Dice que el proyecto le es muy interesante.

Actualmente Maria está solicitando un micro crédito de ¢400.000 (cuatrocientos mil colones) para la compra de semillas de maracuyá. Con esto el espera hacer crecer su negocio y mejorar tanto su calidad de vida como la de su familia. 

Maria es socio de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Delirio, una de las 110 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Maria, 40, lives with her husband and children in a community called Upala de San Carlos which is in the province of Alajuela.
